title: Gardening — Planting Seeds Indoors
description: The child prepares small pots with soil and plants seeds to observe germination. This introduces the life cycle of plants through direct, hands-on experience and builds responsibility through daily watering.
instructions:
1. Gather materials on a tray: small pots, potting soil, seeds (bean or sunflower), watering can, labels, pencil.
2. Demonstrate filling a pot with soil to about 1 inch from the top, pressing gently.
3. Make a small hole with your finger (about 1 inch deep for beans).
4. Place one seed in the hole and cover gently with soil.
5. Write the seed name and date on a label. Place in the pot.
6. Water gently — 'Just enough to make the soil damp, not soggy.'
7. Place pots near a sunny window.
8. Discuss: 'What do seeds need to grow? Sun, water, and soil.'
materials_needed: Small pots or recycled containers with drainage holes
Newspaper or mat for the work surface

slides.setup_instructions: Cover work surface with newspaper. Arrange all materials on a tray from left to right in order of use.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to plant seeds! Seeds are tiny, but they have everything they need inside to become a whole plant.'
Demonstrate filling the pot with soil: 'Scoop the soil gently. Fill the pot to about here — leave room at the top so water doesn't overflow.'
'Now make a little hole with your finger, about this deep.' Show one inch. 'Place ONE seed inside and cover it gently with soil, like tucking it into bed.'
'Write the name of your seed on the label. Write today's date too — we want to know when we planted it!' Place the label in the pot.
'Water very gently — just a little bit. The soil should be damp, not a puddle. Seeds can drown if there's too much water!'

slides.prompt: Plant 2-3 seeds in separate pots. Label each one. Place them near a sunny window. Draw a picture in your journal of what you planted today.

slides.text: Clean up: sweep any spilled soil, wash hands, put away materials. 'Starting tomorrow, check your seeds each day. Water when the soil feels dry on top.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently fill a pot, plant a seed at the correct depth, and water appropriately?

parent_notes: Gardening is a cornerstone Montessori practical life activity that develops patience, responsibility, and scientific observation. Bean seeds germinate quickly (5-7 days) making them ideal for young children who need to see results. Sunflower seeds take a bit longer but are exciting because the plants grow large. This begins a multi-week project: the child will water daily, observe changes, and eventually transplant outdoors. Consider starting a simple garden journal where the child draws observations. Maria Montessori believed that caring for living things develops the child's sense of responsibility and connection to the natural world.

title: Long Vowel Patterns — Silent E (a_e)
description: Introduction to the 'magic e' or 'silent e' pattern where adding an e to the end of a CVC word changes the short vowel to a long vowel. Focuses on the a_e pattern: cap/cape, tap/tape, mat/mate.
instructions:
1. Write 'cap' on a card. Child reads it: /k/-/a/-/p/ = cap.
2. 'Watch what happens when I add a letter.' Place an 'e' at the end: cape.
3. 'The e is magic! It doesn't say anything itself, but it reaches over and changes the /a/ to say its NAME: /ay/. Cap becomes CAPE!'
4. Practice pairs: tap/tape, mat/mate, can/cane, pan/pane, hat/hate, man/mane.
5. Child reads each pair, noting the vowel change.
6. Build a_e words with moveable alphabet: lake, bake, cake, make, game, name, came, same.
materials_needed: Paper and pencil for writing practice

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word pairs on cards (cap/cape, tap/tape, etc.) or have a whiteboard ready. Set out the moveable alphabet.

slides.text: 'You know how to read short vowel words like cap, tap, and mat. Today you'll learn a magic trick that letters can do!'
Build 'cap' with the moveable alphabet. 'Read this word.' Then add 'e' to the end. 'The e is SILENT — it doesn't make a sound. But it's magic!'
'The magic e reaches back over the consonant and taps the vowel, making it say its NAME instead of its sound. /a/ becomes /ay/. Cap becomes CAPE!'
Practice more pairs: tap/tape, mat/mate, can/cane, pan/pane. 'The e changes every short a to a long a!'

slides.prompt: Build these words with the moveable alphabet: lake, bake, cake, game, name, came, save, wave. Read each one aloud.

slides.text: 'Now you know the magic e rule! When you see a vowel-consonant-e at the end of a word, the vowel says its name.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read at least 6 a_e words and explain that the silent e makes the vowel 'say its name'?

parent_notes: The silent e (or 'magic e') pattern is one of the most important phonics rules in English. In Montessori, we often present this as a sensorial discovery: the child sees and hears the transformation from short to long vowel. The key concept is that the e is silent but changes the preceding vowel from its short sound to its long sound (its letter name). Start with a_e this week and introduce i_e and o_e in subsequent lessons. Some children grasp this immediately; others need many repetitions with the word pairs. Using the moveable alphabet lets them physically add and remove the e to see the transformation.

title: Stamp Game — Multiplication Introduction
description: Introduction to multiplication using the stamp game. The child learns that multiplication means 'taking the same number many times' by building repeated groups and combining them.
instructions:
1. 'We're going to learn something new today: multiplication! Multiplication means taking the same number MANY times.'
2. 'Let's try 3 taken 2 times. That means we make the number 3 TWO times.'
3. On the stamp game board, build 3 (three green unit stamps) in the first row.
4. Build 3 again in the second row.
5. 'Now count all the stamps together: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6! 3 taken 2 times equals 6.'
6. Practice: 4 taken 2 times, 2 taken 3 times, 5 taken 2 times.
7. Introduce the multiplication sign: 3 x 2 = 6.
materials_needed: Small paper strips for writing equations

items: Stamp game with stamps and board
slides.setup_instructions: Set out the stamp game on the mat. Have paper ready for writing equations.

slides.text: 'You already know addition — putting numbers together. Multiplication is a SPECIAL kind of addition. It means taking the SAME number again and again!'
'3 taken 2 times: make a group of 3 green stamps. Now make ANOTHER group of 3 green stamps right below it.'
'How many do we have altogether? Count them all!' Child counts: 6. 'So 3 taken 2 times is 6! We write it: 3 x 2 = 6.'
'The x means TIMES — how many times we take that number. Let's try 4 taken 2 times.' Build two rows of 4 stamps.

slides.prompt: Use the stamp game to solve: 2 x 3, 5 x 2, 4 x 3, 3 x 3. Build each group, count the total, and write the equation on paper.

slides.text: 'Multiplication is really fast addition! Instead of 3 + 3, we can say 3 x 2. You'll see — multiplication is very powerful!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build repeated groups with stamps and count the total for at least 3 multiplication problems?

parent_notes: Montessori introduces multiplication concretely before any memorization of facts. The stamp game makes multiplication visible: the child physically builds identical groups and counts the result. The language 'taken X times' is traditional Montessori phrasing and helps the child understand what the operation means. At this stage, keep multiplicands small (2-5) and multipliers small (2-3) so the child can count the result easily. Do not rush to the times tables — deep understanding of the concept comes first. The child should see that 3 x 2 means 'make 3, two times' and then count to verify.

title: Spring Around the World
description: Exploring how spring looks different in various parts of the world. The child learns that while it is spring in the Northern Hemisphere, it is autumn in the Southern Hemisphere, connecting to earlier globe and hemisphere work.
instructions:
1. Look at the globe together. Review: 'Remember the equator — the invisible line around the middle of Earth?'
2. 'When it is spring HERE (point to Northern Hemisphere), it is FALL on the other side (point to Southern Hemisphere).'
3. Show pictures of spring in different countries: cherry blossoms in Japan, tulips in the Netherlands, monsoon rains in India.
4. 'What does spring look like where WE live?' Discuss local signs of spring.
5. The child draws or colors a picture showing spring in two different hemispheres.
6. Label the drawings: 'Spring' and 'Autumn.'
materials_needed: Pictures of spring in different countries

items: Pictures of spring scenes from different countries
slides.setup_instructions: Gather pictures showing spring in at least 3 different countries. Have the globe accessible.

slides.text: 'It's springtime! But did you know that RIGHT NOW, on the other side of the world, it's autumn? Let's find out why!'
Show the globe. 'The Earth is tilted. When our part (Northern Hemisphere) tilts toward the sun, we get spring and summer. The other side gets fall and winter!'
Show pictures: 'In Japan, spring means beautiful cherry blossoms. In the Netherlands, millions of tulips bloom. What happens where we live?'

slides.prompt: Draw two pictures side by side: spring in the Northern Hemisphere and autumn in the Southern Hemisphere. Label each drawing and the hemisphere.

slides.text: 'The Earth is amazing — people all over the world experience different seasons at the same time!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain that opposite hemispheres have opposite seasons?

parent_notes: This lesson connects the child's direct experience of spring to a broader geographic understanding. Montessori education emphasizes cosmic education — helping the child see themselves as part of a larger whole. The concept that hemispheres have opposite seasons is fascinating to young children and builds on earlier work with the globe. If possible, look outside together and note signs of spring: buds on trees, longer days, warmer temperatures, birds returning. This grounds the abstract concept in the child's lived experience.

title: Read-Aloud: From Seed to Plant by Gail Gibbons
description: Reading 'From Seed to Plant' by Gail Gibbons, a clear nonfiction book explaining the life cycle of plants from seed to flower, including pollination and seed dispersal.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'We've been learning about seeds and plants. Let's learn more!'
2. Read aloud, pausing at the clear diagrams and labels.
3. Discuss each stage: seed, germination, roots, stem, leaves, flower, fruit, new seeds.
4. Point out the pollination page: 'Remember how bees help flowers?'
5. Review seed dispersal methods: wind, water, animals.
6. Connect to plants you've observed or grown.
materials_needed: From Seed to Plant by Gail Gibbons
Optional: bean seeds and wet paper towel for germination

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: From Seed to Plant by Gail Gibbons

items: Optional: bean seeds for germination experiment
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Consider starting a germination observation.

slides.text: Cover: 'Gail Gibbons is going to teach us exactly how a tiny seed becomes a big plant. Let's follow the journey!'
Read through each stage clearly. Gail Gibbons' labeled diagrams are perfect for learning plant vocabulary.
Discuss: 'What does a seed need to germinate? How do seeds travel to new places? What is pollination?'

slides.prompt: Draw the life cycle of a plant: seed, sprout, plant, flower, fruit, new seed. Label each stage!

slides.text: 'From a tiny seed to a big plant and back to seeds again — it's a circle of life!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe at least three stages of a plant's life cycle?

parent_notes: Gail Gibbons' nonfiction is perfectly suited to Montessori's concrete-to-abstract approach. This book provides clear scientific illustrations that complement hands-on botany work. Consider the bean germination experiment at the back of the book — watching a seed sprout in a wet paper towel is a classic Montessori activity.

title: Constructive Triangles — Exploration with Hexagonal Box
description: The child uses the hexagonal box of constructive triangles to discover that triangles can combine to form hexagons, rhombuses, and parallelograms. This deepens understanding of how shapes relate to one another.
instructions:
1. Open the hexagonal box. 'All of these pieces are triangles. Let's see what shapes we can build!'
2. Take two green triangles. Place them together along the black line: 'A rhombus!'
3. Take three red triangles. Join along black lines: 'A trapezoid!'
4. Take all six yellow triangles. Join them: 'A hexagon! Six triangles make a hexagon!'
5. Let the child experiment: 'What other shapes can you make with these triangles?'
6. Name each shape the child creates.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the mat. Open the hexagonal box and spread the triangles out so the child can see them all.

slides.text: 'Remember the constructive triangles? Today we have the hexagonal box. All the pieces are triangles — but watch what shapes they can make!'
'Take two green triangles. Match the black lines together.' The child joins them. 'What shape did you make? A RHOMBUS — like a diamond!'
'Now try three red triangles together.' Join along the black lines. 'This shape is called a TRAPEZOID!'
'Can you use ALL six yellow triangles to make one big shape?' Guide if needed. 'A HEXAGON — a shape with six sides!'

slides.prompt: Experiment freely! How many different shapes can you make by combining different triangles? Try 2, 3, 4, and 6 triangles together.

slides.text: 'Triangles are amazing — they can build so many other shapes! Every shape you made was built from triangles.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child construct a hexagon from 6 triangles and name at least 2 shapes made from combining triangles?

parent_notes: The constructive triangles are a brilliant Montessori material that reveals a fundamental geometric truth: all polygons can be divided into triangles. The hexagonal box specifically shows that a hexagon is composed of 6 equilateral triangles. The black lines on the triangle edges guide the child to correct pairings. Let the child discover and experiment — if they create an unexpected shape, name it and celebrate the discovery. This work prepares for later geometry, including understanding area as a concept built from triangles.

title: Long Vowel Patterns — Silent E (i_e)
description: Extending the magic e pattern to i_e words. The child discovers that the same silent e rule applies: adding e changes the short i (/ih/) to long i (/eye/). Pairs: bit/bite, kit/kite, fin/fine, hid/hide.
instructions:
1. Review a_e: 'Remember the magic e? It makes the vowel say its name. Cap becomes cape.'
2. 'Today the magic e works on the letter i!' Write 'bit' — child reads it.
3. Add e: 'bite!' 'The short /ih/ changed to long /eye/ — i says its name!'
4. Practice pairs: kit/kite, fin/fine, hid/hide, pin/pine, dim/dime, rip/ripe.
5. Build i_e words with moveable alphabet: like, bike, hike, time, line, vine, ride, side.
6. Child reads all words aloud.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word pair cards (bit/bite, kit/kite, etc.). Set out the moveable alphabet.

slides.text: 'Remember the magic e from yesterday? It changed /a/ to /ay/ in words like cape and lake. Today the magic e will work on the letter i!'
Build 'bit' with the moveable alphabet. Child reads: 'bit.' Add e: 'Now read it!' BITE. 'The /ih/ changed to /eye/!'
More pairs: kit/kite — 'A kit is a set of tools. A kite flies in the sky!' fin/fine, hid/hide, pin/pine.
'The magic e rule works the same way: the e is silent, but it makes the i say its name — /eye/.'

slides.prompt: Build these i_e words: like, bike, hike, time, line, vine, ride, side, five, nine. Read each one. Can you use 3 of them in sentences?

slides.text: 'Now you know TWO magic e patterns: a_e and i_e! Tomorrow we'll learn another one.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read at least 6 i_e words and distinguish short i from long i in word pairs?

parent_notes: Building on yesterday's a_e lesson, i_e follows the same pattern. The power of this approach is that the child discovers the RULE — not just individual words. Once they understand that silent e changes the vowel, they can decode thousands of words they have never seen before. The word pairs (bit/bite, kit/kite) make the transformation concrete and memorable. If the child confuses short and long i, go back to the pairs and emphasize the contrast. Some children enjoy the drama of the 'magic e' — you can make a little wand and have them 'cast the spell' on each word!

title: Introduction to Skip Counting Chains — Chain of 2
description: The child uses the short bead chain of 2 to count by twos. Each bead bar has 2 beads, and the child places number arrows at each bar to build the skip counting sequence: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10...
instructions:
1. Bring out the short chain of 2 (five bars of 2 beads connected by links).
2. Lay the chain in a straight line on the mat.
3. 'Each bar has 2 beads. Let's count by 2s!' Touch the end of each bar: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10.
4. Place the number arrow '2' at the end of the first bar, '4' at the second, and so on.
5. 'We call this skip counting — we skip a number each time: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10!'
6. Remove the arrows. Child places them independently.
7. Count the chain forward and backward.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out a long floor mat. Have the chain and arrows ready in a cup or small box.

slides.text: 'This is the chain of 2. Each little bar has 2 beads. Let's stretch it out on the mat in a long line!'
'Let's count by 2s. Touch the end of each bar with me: 2... 4... 6... 8... 10!'
'Now let's mark each count with an arrow.' Place the arrow labeled '2' after the first bar, '4' after the second, and so on.
'Look at the pattern: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10. We skipped all the odd numbers! This is called SKIP COUNTING.'

slides.prompt: Remove all the arrows. Now YOU place them at the right spots! Count by 2s as you go. Then try counting backward: 10, 8, 6, 4, 2!

slides.text: 'You can count by 2s! This is also connected to multiplication — 2 taken 5 times is 10, just like our chain!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child place all number arrows correctly on the chain of 2 and recite the skip counting sequence?

parent_notes: The bead chains are one of Montessori's most elegant math materials. The chain of 2 physically shows what skip counting means — the child touches and counts real beads. This concrete experience builds the foundation for multiplication tables later. The number arrows help the child see the pattern visually. Once the chain is laid out with all arrows, the child can see the entire skip counting sequence at a glance. Counting backward (10, 8, 6, 4, 2) is also important — it prepares for subtraction and division. Let the child work with this chain many times; repetition builds fluency.

title: Life Cycle of a Butterfly — Egg and Caterpillar Stages
description: Beginning a multi-lesson exploration of the butterfly life cycle. Today focuses on the first two stages: egg and caterpillar (larva). The child learns that butterflies begin as tiny eggs on leaves and hatch into hungry caterpillars.
instructions:
1. 'Today we begin learning about one of nature's most amazing transformations — how a butterfly is born!'
2. Show a picture or model of a butterfly egg on a leaf. 'A butterfly lays tiny, tiny eggs on leaves. Each egg is smaller than a grain of rice!'
3. 'Inside the egg, a caterpillar is growing. When it's ready, it hatches!' Show image of a tiny caterpillar.
4. 'The caterpillar's job is to EAT. It eats leaves all day long and grows bigger and bigger.'
5. 'As it grows, its skin gets too tight. It molts — sheds its old skin — and has a new, bigger skin underneath!'
6. Child draws the egg stage and caterpillar stage in their science journal.
7. Label: 'Egg' and 'Caterpillar (Larva).'
materials_needed: Pictures of butterfly eggs and caterpillars
Butterfly life cycle model or chart (optional)

items: Pictures of butterfly eggs and caterpillars
slides.setup_instructions: Gather pictures showing butterfly eggs (close-up) and caterpillars at different sizes. If you have a butterfly garden kit, this is the time to start it!

slides.text: 'Butterflies are so beautiful, but they don't start out that way! They go through an amazing change. Let's find out how it begins.'
'A mother butterfly lays tiny eggs on a leaf. Look at this picture — the eggs are SO small! Inside each egg, a caterpillar is growing.'
'When the egg hatches, out comes a tiny caterpillar! What do you think the caterpillar does? It EATS! It eats and eats and grows and grows.'
'The caterpillar grows so much that it has to shed its skin — like taking off a shirt that's too small! This is called molting.'

slides.prompt: In your science journal, draw the first two stages: 1) A tiny egg on a leaf, 2) A caterpillar eating leaves. Label each stage.

slides.text: 'We learned the first two stages: egg and caterpillar. Next time, we'll find out what happens when the caterpillar is done eating!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe what happens in the egg stage and caterpillar stage of the butterfly life cycle?

parent_notes: The butterfly life cycle is a quintessential Montessori science study because it demonstrates metamorphosis — complete transformation — in a way children can observe directly. If possible, order a butterfly garden kit (painted lady butterflies) so the child can watch the entire process over 3-4 weeks. The caterpillar stage fascinates children: it eats constantly and molts several times. Connecting this to the child's own growth ('You've outgrown clothes too!') makes it relatable. We'll cover chrysalis and adult stages in later lessons. The science journal drawing reinforces vocabulary and sequencing.

title: Watercolor Painting — Spring Flowers
description: The child uses watercolors to paint spring flowers, practicing brush control, color mixing, and creative expression. This connects to the gardening and nature themes of the week.
instructions:
1. Set up watercolor station: paper, watercolors, water cup, brush, paper towels.
2. 'Today we are going to paint spring flowers! What flowers do you know?'
3. Demonstrate: wet the brush, touch one color, paint a simple petal shape on your paper.
4. 'To make different colors, you can mix! Yellow and red make orange. Yellow and blue make green.'
5. Show how to paint stems (green) and a simple flower shape.
6. 'Now you paint your own spring garden! You can use any colors you like.'
7. Let the child paint freely, offering guidance only if asked.
8. When finished, sign the painting and let it dry flat.
materials_needed: Watercolor paper or thick white paper
Mat or newspaper to protect surface

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the work surface. Fill the water cup. Lay out paints, paper, and brushes. Have the child put on a smock.

slides.text: 'It's spring! Flowers are blooming everywhere. Today we will paint our own spring garden with watercolors.'
Demonstrate: 'Dip your brush in water, then touch the color. Paint a petal shape like this.' Show a simple oval or circle petal.
'You can mix colors! Watch: yellow and blue make GREEN for stems and leaves. Red and yellow make ORANGE.'
'Paint your own spring garden. Flowers can be any shape and any color you imagine!'

slides.prompt: Paint a spring garden with at least 3 different flowers. Try mixing colors to create new ones. Add stems, leaves, and maybe a sun or butterfly!

slides.text: Sign your painting with your name. Clean your brushes by swirling in water and drying with a paper towel. Let the painting dry flat.
slides.mastery_check: Did the child use watercolor techniques (wetting brush, mixing colors, brush control) to create a painting?

parent_notes: Montessori art emphasizes process over product — the experience of painting matters more than what the final result looks like. Resist the urge to direct the child's creative choices. Your role is to demonstrate the technique (how to hold the brush, how to load paint, how to mix colors) and then step back. Watercolors teach patience because you must wait for layers to dry and work with the water's flow rather than against it. If the child is frustrated, suggest experimenting on a practice paper first. Display the finished painting — it validates the child's effort and builds confidence.

title: Gardening — Watering and Observing Seedlings
description: The child practices the daily routine of checking on planted seeds, watering when needed, and recording observations. This builds patience, responsibility, and early scientific observation skills.
instructions:
1. Go to the seed pots planted on Day 1.
2. 'First, let's observe. Look closely. Has anything changed?'
3. Touch the soil: 'Is it dry or damp? If it's dry on top, we need to water.'
4. Demonstrate gentle watering. 'Just a little — the soil should be moist, not flooded.'
5. 'Even though we can't SEE anything yet, the seed is working hard underground. Water is softening the seed coat.'
6. In the garden journal, draw what the pot looks like today. Write the date.
7. 'We'll check again tomorrow! Seeds take time — this is patience work.'

slides.setup_instructions: Bring the seed pots to the work area. Have the journal and watering can ready.

slides.text: 'Let's check on our seeds! Remember, we planted them two days ago. Let's be seed detectives today.'
'First, LOOK. Do you see anything poking out of the soil? Not yet? That's okay — the seed is working underground!'
'Now FEEL the soil gently with your finger. Is it dry or still damp? If it's dry, we water. If it's damp, the seed has enough.'
'Water gently if needed. Let's draw what we see in our garden journal. Write today's date. Even if nothing has changed, that's an observation!'

slides.prompt: Check each pot. Water if needed. In your journal, draw the pot and write: 'Day 3: Soil is ___. No sprout yet / I see ___.' Date your entry.

slides.text: 'Scientists record observations every day, even when nothing seems to change. You are being a real scientist! We'll check again tomorrow.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child assess soil moisture, water appropriately, and record a dated observation?

parent_notes: This seemingly simple activity teaches profound lessons. The child is learning delayed gratification — they planted seeds and must wait days or weeks to see results. Recording observations, even 'nothing changed,' teaches the scientific method. Montessori valued patience and the ability to wait as essential character traits. If the child is impatient, reassure them: 'The seed is busy underground. The shell is softening, the root is starting to grow. We just can't see it yet.' If you have bean seeds, sprouts may appear within 5-7 days, which keeps motivation high.

title: Long Vowel Patterns — Silent E (o_e)
description: Completing the magic e introduction with o_e words. The child now knows three silent e patterns (a_e, i_e, o_e) and can decode words like hope, home, bone, note, and code.
instructions:
1. Quick review: 'What does magic e do? Makes the vowel say its name! We know a_e (cape, lake) and i_e (bike, time).'
2. 'Today: the letter o! Watch.' Write 'hop.' Child reads: /h/-/o/-/p/ = hop.
3. Add e: 'hope!' 'The short /o/ changed to long /oh/ — o says its name!'
4. Practice pairs: hop/hope, not/note, cod/code, rob/robe, rod/rode.
5. Build o_e words: home, bone, cone, stone, phone, stove, those, woke.
6. Mixed review: read a_e, i_e, and o_e words mixed together.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare o_e word pairs. Also have a few a_e and i_e words for the mixed review at the end.

slides.text: 'We know two magic e patterns already! a_e makes /ay/ and i_e makes /eye/. Today the magic e works on the letter o!'
Build 'hop.' Child reads: 'hop.' Add e. 'Hope! The /o/ sound changed to /oh/ — the o says its name now!'
More pairs: not/note, cod/code, rob/robe, rod/rode. 'Each time, the e changes the short o to long o!'
Build new o_e words: home, bone, cone, stone, woke, those. 'You're reading so many new words!'

slides.prompt: Mixed challenge! Read these words — some are a_e, some are i_e, some are o_e: cake, bike, home, late, fine, stone, name, ride, hope. Sort them into three groups!

slides.text: 'You now know three magic e patterns! a_e, i_e, and o_e. That's hundreds of new words you can read!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read o_e words and sort a mixed list of a_e, i_e, and o_e words correctly?

parent_notes: With three silent e patterns now in the child's toolkit, they can decode a huge number of English words. The mixed review at the end is important — it requires the child to look at the vowel AND the silent e together to determine the pronunciation. If the child struggles with sorting, focus on the vowel: 'What vowel do you see? A, I, or O? That's the group!' Note that u_e and e_e exist too but are less common and can be introduced later. The power of understanding the RULE rather than memorizing individual words is enormous — this is why Montessori phonics instruction is so effective.

title: Skip Counting Chain — Chain of 3
description: The child uses the short bead chain of 3 to count by threes. Each bar has 3 beads, and number arrows mark the skip counting sequence: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27.
instructions:
1. Bring out the short chain of 3 (nine bars of 3 beads connected by links).
2. Lay it in a straight line on the floor mat.
3. 'Each bar has 3 beads. Let's count by 3s!' Touch the end of each bar: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27.
4. Place number arrows at each bar.
5. 'Count by 3s with me — use the arrows to help: 3, 6, 9, 12...'
6. Remove arrows. Child places them independently.
7. 'Notice: 3, 6, 9 — that's 3 taken 3 times = 9. That's the square of 3!'

slides.setup_instructions: This chain is longer than the chain of 2! Make sure you have a long stretch of floor or table space.

slides.text: 'Today we have the chain of 3! Each bar has 3 beads. Let's stretch it out and count by 3s!'
Touch the end of each bar together: '3... 6... 9... 12... 15... 18... 21... 24... 27! That's a lot of 3s!'
'Let's place the arrows.' Place '3' at the first bar, '6' at the second, etc. 'The arrows show us the skip counting pattern.'
'Look: 3, 6, 9 — three 3s make 9. That's 3 times 3! We call 9 the SQUARE of 3.'

slides.prompt: Remove all arrows and place them back yourself. Count by 3s forward and backward. Can you say the sequence without looking? 3, 6, 9, 12...

slides.mastery_check: Can the child place arrows correctly on the chain of 3 and recite the skip counting sequence to at least 18?

parent_notes: The chain of 3 is longer and more challenging than the chain of 2, but the process is identical. The child counts by 3s while touching each bar. The concept of the square (3 x 3 = 9) is introduced naturally — you can fold the chain into a square shape to show this visually. Don't require memorization of the sequence yet; the goal is familiarity through repeated physical counting. Some children enjoy singing or chanting the sequence, which aids memory. The bead chains eventually lead to understanding multiplication, squaring, and cubing — all through concrete, hands-on experience.

title: Spring Festivals Around the World — Holi and Nowruz
description: Learning about two spring celebrations from different cultures: Holi (the Hindu festival of colors) and Nowruz (Persian New Year). Children discover that many cultures celebrate the arrival of spring.
instructions:
1. 'People all over the world celebrate spring! Today we'll learn about two special festivals.'
2. Holi: Show pictures. 'In India, people throw colored powder and water at each other to celebrate spring! It's called Holi — the festival of colors.'
3. 'Holi celebrates the victory of good over evil and the arrival of spring. Everyone plays together — children and adults!'
4. Nowruz: 'In Iran and many other countries, Nowruz is the New Year! It happens on the first day of spring.'
5. 'Families set a special table called a Haft-Sin with 7 items that start with the letter S in Persian.'
6. Find India and Iran on the world map.
7. Art project: create a colorful Holi-inspired painting using chalk pastels or finger paints.
materials_needed: Pictures of Holi and Nowruz celebrations

slides.setup_instructions: Gather colorful pictures of both festivals. Have India and Iran located on the map.

slides.text: 'When spring arrives, people everywhere celebrate! Today we'll learn about two amazing spring festivals from different parts of the world.'
Show Holi pictures: 'This is HOLI — the Festival of Colors! In India, people throw bright colored powder at each other. Everyone gets covered in beautiful colors!'
'NOWRUZ is the Persian New Year. It's celebrated on the first day of spring! Families make a special table with 7 things that start with the letter S in the Persian language.'
Find India and Iran on the map. 'These countries are far apart, but both celebrate spring! Spring means new life and new beginnings everywhere.'

slides.prompt: Create a Holi-inspired artwork! Use chalk pastels or finger paints to make a colorful explosion of spring colors. Mix and blend as many colors as you can!

slides.text: 'People all over the world celebrate spring in their own special ways. What's similar? Everyone is happy that warm weather and flowers are coming!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name both festivals and the countries where they are celebrated?

parent_notes: Montessori's cultural curriculum emphasizes respect for all peoples and customs. Learning about celebrations from other cultures builds empathy and broadens the child's worldview. Holi is visually stunning and children love the idea of throwing colors. Nowruz (literally 'new day') has been celebrated for over 3,000 years. The Haft-Sin table items (sprouts, garlic, apples, etc.) all symbolize aspects of life and renewal. You can extend this lesson by making your own 'spring table' with items that represent the season to your family. Emphasize what these celebrations have in common: joy, family, gratitude for spring.

title: Read-Aloud: The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle
description: Reading this beloved classic about a caterpillar that eats through various foods before building a cocoon and emerging as a butterfly. Connects to the butterfly life cycle science lesson.
instructions:
1. Show the cover: 'We're learning about caterpillars and butterflies this week. This story is about a VERY hungry caterpillar!'
2. Read the story. On each food page, let the child count the items and poke fingers through the holes.
3. 'On Monday he ate through ONE apple. On Tuesday he ate through TWO pears...' Count together.
4. When the caterpillar eats junk food and gets a stomachache: 'What happened? Why did his tummy hurt?'
5. 'Then he ate one nice green leaf and felt much better.'
6. The cocoon and butterfly pages: 'This is what we learned about in science! Metamorphosis!'
7. Retell: 'What did the caterpillar eat on Wednesday?'
materials_needed: The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle

slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably where the child can see the pictures and touch the die-cut holes in the pages.

slides.text: 'Remember what we learned about caterpillars in science? This is a story about a caterpillar with a BIG appetite!'
Read with enthusiasm. Count the foods on each page: 'One apple, two pears, three plums...' Let the child poke fingers through the holes.
At the junk food pages: 'Uh oh! A stomachache! What could help?' Then: 'One nice green leaf. He felt much better.'

slides.prompt: After reading, retell the story: 'What did he eat on each day? What happened at the end?' Can you act out the caterpillar eating and then becoming a butterfly?

slides.text: 'The caterpillar ate, grew, built a cocoon, and became a beautiful butterfly — just like the real butterflies we're studying!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sequence the days and foods and connect the story to the real butterfly life cycle?

parent_notes: Even if your child has heard this story many times, reading it now — while studying the butterfly life cycle — gives it new meaning. The counting element (1 apple, 2 pears, 3 plums, 4 strawberries, 5 oranges) reinforces number sequence. The healthy eating message (junk food causes a stomachache, a green leaf helps) is gentle but clear. Note that Eric Carle uses 'cocoon' rather than the scientifically accurate 'chrysalis' for butterflies — you can gently mention this distinction: 'In the story it's called a cocoon, but scientists call a butterfly's special covering a chrysalis.'

title: Geometric Cabinet — Curved Figures Drawer
description: The child works with the geometric cabinet's curved figures drawer, tracing and naming the circle, ellipse, oval, and curvilinear triangle. Develops visual discrimination and vocabulary for curved shapes.
instructions:
1. Take out the curved figures drawer from the geometric cabinet.
2. Remove the circle inset. Trace the frame (outside), then the inset (inside) with two fingers.
3. 'This is a circle. It curves the same amount all the way around.'
4. Remove the ellipse: 'This is an ellipse. It's like a stretched circle — longer in one direction.'
5. Remove the oval: 'This is an oval. It looks like an egg — one end is slightly bigger.'
6. Remove the curvilinear triangle: 'This shape has three curved sides!'
7. Three-period lesson for the names.
8. Child traces each shape and matches insets to frames.
materials_needed: Paper and colored pencils for tracing (optional)

items: Optional: paper and colored pencils for tracing
slides.setup_instructions: Place the drawer on the mat. The child should be able to reach all insets easily.

slides.text: 'Today we're exploring shapes with CURVES — no straight lines at all! Let's start with one you know.'
Remove the circle: 'Trace around the frame, then around the inset. Feel how it curves the same amount everywhere? This is a CIRCLE.'
Ellipse: 'This looks like a circle that got stretched! It's called an ELLIPSE. Trace it — feel how it's longer one way?'
Oval: 'An OVAL looks like an egg. See how one end is a little pointier?' Curvilinear triangle: 'Three CURVED sides!'

slides.prompt: Three-period lesson: 'Show me the ellipse. Show me the oval. Which one is this?' Then trace each shape on paper with a colored pencil.

slides.text: 'You know four curved shapes now: circle, ellipse, oval, and curvilinear triangle. Look for these shapes in the world around you!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and trace all four curved figures and distinguish the ellipse from the oval?

parent_notes: The geometric cabinet is a key Montessori sensorial material. The curved figures drawer helps the child see subtle differences between similar shapes. The distinction between ellipse and oval is surprisingly nuanced — an ellipse is symmetrical on both axes, while an oval is only symmetrical on one (like an egg, wider at one end). Children don't need to articulate this mathematically; they absorb the difference through tracing and comparing. The two-finger tracing technique develops the light touch needed for writing while building shape recognition. If you don't have the geometric cabinet, you can make cardboard insets of these shapes.

title: Reading Longer Stories — Decodable Readers with Silent E
description: The child reads a short decodable story that includes silent e words alongside CVC words. This puts the new phonics pattern into context and builds reading fluency and comprehension.
instructions:
1. Choose a decodable reader that features a_e, i_e, and o_e words (or write a short story together).
2. Example text: 'Jake rode his bike to the lake. He came at five. Kate made a cake. They ate by the stone.'
3. Child reads the story aloud. Help with any difficult words by reminding: 'Is there a magic e?'
4. After reading, ask comprehension questions: 'Where did Jake ride? What did Kate make?'
5. Read the story a second time for fluency.
6. 'Can you find all the magic e words in the story?' Child circles or points to them.
materials_needed: Decodable reader with silent e words

items: Decodable reader or printed story with silent e words
slides.setup_instructions: Select or print a decodable story that features silent e words mixed with CVC words. The story should be 4-8 sentences long.

slides.text: 'You've learned the magic e patterns this week. Now let's read a STORY that uses those words! Stories are what reading is all about.'
Child reads the story aloud. If they hesitate on a word: 'Look carefully. Do you see an e at the end? What does that tell you?'
After reading: 'Tell me what happened in the story. Who are the characters? What did they do?'
'Now let's be word detectives! Can you find all the magic e words in the story? Point to each one.'

slides.prompt: Read the story two more times. Each time, try to read a little more smoothly. Then find and list all the silent e words you see.

slides.text: 'You just read a whole story with magic e words! The more you read, the easier it gets.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read the decodable story with reasonable fluency and answer 2-3 comprehension questions?

parent_notes: Reading decodable stories is the bridge between phonics lessons and real reading. The child sees the patterns they've learned in meaningful context. If you don't have a commercial decodable reader, write a simple story using a_e, i_e, and o_e words mixed with CVC words the child already knows. Keep sentences short and the story simple but interesting. Reading the same story multiple times builds fluency — each re-reading is smoother and more confident. Comprehension questions ensure the child is reading for meaning, not just decoding. Celebrate their progress: 'You're reading stories now!'

title: Stamp Game Multiplication — Two-Digit Numbers
description: Extending stamp game multiplication to two-digit numbers. The child builds a two-digit number multiple times and combines the results, practicing exchange when units exceed 10.
instructions:
1. 'Remember multiplication? Taking a number many times. Today we'll multiply bigger numbers!'
2. Problem: 12 taken 3 times (12 x 3).
3. Build 12 three times on the stamp game: each group has 1 blue ten stamp and 2 green unit stamps.
4. Combine all the ten stamps: 1 + 1 + 1 = 3 tens.
5. Combine all the unit stamps: 2 + 2 + 2 = 6 units.
6. Result: 36! Write: 12 x 3 = 36.
7. Try 14 x 2: build 14 twice. 1+1 = 2 tens, 4+4 = 8 units = 28.
8. Try 13 x 3: 3 tens + 9 units = 39.
materials_needed: Paper and pencil for recording equations

slides.setup_instructions: Set out the stamp game. Have enough space for building multiple groups. Paper ready for recording.

slides.text: 'You've been multiplying small numbers. Now let's try BIGGER numbers! 12 taken 3 times. That means we build 12 THREE times.'
Build first group: 1 blue ten stamp, 2 green unit stamps. 'That's 12.' Build second and third groups the same way.
'Now combine! How many tens? 1 + 1 + 1 = 3 tens. How many units? 2 + 2 + 2 = 6 units. 36!'
Write: 12 x 3 = 36. 'Let's try another: 14 taken 2 times.' Build, combine, record.

slides.prompt: Solve these with the stamp game: 11 x 4, 15 x 2, 13 x 3. Build each group, combine, and write the equation.

slides.text: 'You can multiply two-digit numbers! The stamp game helps us see what happens when we take a number many times.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build a two-digit number multiple times, combine the stamps correctly, and state the product?

parent_notes: Moving to two-digit multiplication is exciting because the child works with both tens and units simultaneously. The stamp game makes this manageable — each category (tens, units) is combined separately. At this stage, we're choosing problems where units don't exceed 9 when combined (to avoid exchange). Once the child is comfortable, you can introduce problems requiring exchange (like 16 x 2, where 6+6=12 units requires exchanging 10 units for 1 ten). The key principle: multiplication is repeated addition, and the stamp game makes this visible and concrete.

title: Life Cycle of a Butterfly — Chrysalis Stage
description: Continuing the butterfly life cycle study with the chrysalis (pupa) stage. The child learns that the caterpillar forms a chrysalis and undergoes metamorphosis — a complete transformation — inside.
instructions:
1. Review: 'What have we learned so far? Egg, then caterpillar. The caterpillar eats and grows. What happens next?'
2. 'When the caterpillar is big enough, something amazing happens. It attaches itself to a branch and forms a hard shell called a CHRYSALIS.'
3. Show pictures of a chrysalis. 'It might look like nothing is happening, but INSIDE, the caterpillar is completely changing!'
4. 'This change is called METAMORPHOSIS. The caterpillar's body breaks down and rebuilds into something completely new.'
5. 'It's like the greatest magic trick in nature — a crawling caterpillar becomes a flying butterfly!'
6. Child draws the chrysalis stage in their science journal and labels it.
7. Update the life cycle diagram: egg, caterpillar, chrysalis.
materials_needed: Life cycle diagram from previous lesson

slides.setup_instructions: Gather pictures showing the caterpillar attaching and forming a chrysalis. Have the journal with previous drawings ready.

slides.text: 'Remember our caterpillar? It ate and ate and grew. When it's finally big enough, it's ready for the next step. Something incredible!'
'The caterpillar finds a safe spot on a branch. It attaches itself and forms a hard covering called a CHRYSALIS.' Show pictures.
'Inside the chrysalis, the caterpillar is COMPLETELY changing. Its body breaks apart and rebuilds into something new. This is called METAMORPHOSIS.'
'It takes about 10-14 days. On the outside, nothing seems to happen. But inside, an amazing transformation is occurring!'

slides.prompt: Draw the chrysalis stage in your journal. Label it 'Chrysalis (Pupa)' and write one sentence: 'Inside the chrysalis, the caterpillar changes into a butterfly.'

slides.text: 'Three stages done: egg, caterpillar, chrysalis. Next time we'll find out what comes OUT of the chrysalis!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what happens inside a chrysalis and use the word metamorphosis?

parent_notes: The chrysalis stage is the most mysterious and magical part of the butterfly life cycle. Inside, the caterpillar essentially liquefies and reassembles into a butterfly — this is genuine transformation, not just growth. Children are often amazed that the 'boring' shell is hiding such dramatic change. Distinguish between chrysalis (butterfly) and cocoon (moth) — moths spin silk cocoons, while butterflies form a hard chrysalis from their skin. If you have a butterfly garden kit, the children can watch their own caterpillars form chrysalises, making the wait tangible and exciting. Patience is a key virtue being developed here.

title: Music — Singing Spring Songs and Rhythm Instruments
description: Learning and singing spring-themed songs while keeping rhythm with percussion instruments. The child develops musical awareness, rhythm, and vocal expression.
instructions:
1. 'Spring is a time for singing! Many songs celebrate spring.'
2. Teach a simple spring song (e.g., 'Spring is Here' to a simple melody, or 'It's Raining, It's Pouring').
3. Sing together several times until the child knows the words.
4. Introduce rhythm instruments: shakers, tambourine, rhythm sticks, or homemade instruments.
5. 'Now let's add rhythm! Shake on the BEAT.' Demonstrate the steady beat.
6. Sing the song again with instruments.
7. 'Let's try a different instrument. Does it change how the song feels?'
8. Free exploration: child plays and sings independently.
materials_needed: Rhythm instruments (shakers, tambourine, rhythm sticks, triangle)

slides.setup_instructions: Gather instruments. If you don't have them, make shakers from rice in a sealed container, or use wooden spoons as rhythm sticks.

slides.text: 'Spring is here and we're going to celebrate with music! Let's learn a spring song together.'
Sing the song slowly, line by line. The child echoes each line. Repeat until the child can sing along with you.
'Now let's add instruments! Listen for the BEAT — that's the steady pulse of the music, like a heartbeat.' Demonstrate: tap-tap-tap-tap.
'Shake your instrument on the beat while we sing! Ready?' Sing together with instruments.

slides.prompt: Try each instrument with the song. Which is your favorite? Now try making up your OWN spring song! What would you sing about?

slides.text: Put instruments away carefully in their places. 'Music is a wonderful way to celebrate the seasons! You can sing your spring song anytime.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child maintain a steady beat with an instrument while singing?

parent_notes: Music in Montessori is about joyful expression, not performance. The goal is for the child to feel rhythm in their body, match a steady beat, and express themselves vocally. Keeping the beat is a fundamental musical skill — it requires coordination between hearing and movement. If the child struggles to play and sing simultaneously, have them do one at a time first. Homemade instruments work just as well as purchased ones: a sealed container with rice or beans makes a great shaker, wooden spoons are rhythm sticks, and a metal pot lid with a spoon is a cymbal. Sing with your child — modeling is the best teaching.

title: Outdoor Practical Life — Nature Walk and Collection
description: A nature walk focused on observing signs of spring. The child collects natural items (leaves, petals, interesting stones) and practices careful observation, classification, and respect for the environment.
instructions:
1. Prepare for the walk: 'We're going on a nature walk to look for signs of spring!'
2. Give the child a small bag or basket for collecting.
3. Walk slowly. Stop frequently: 'What do you notice? What's different from winter?'
4. Look for: buds on trees, flowers blooming, insects, birds, green grass emerging.
5. Collect carefully: 'We take only what has already fallen — leaves, petals on the ground. We don't pick living flowers.'
6. Return home and arrange the nature collection on a tray.
7. Sort items: 'What categories can we make? Things that are green, things that are soft...'

slides.setup_instructions: Dress for the weather. Choose a walking route with natural areas: yard, park, garden, or trail.

slides.text: 'Today we're going outside to explore! It's spring, and nature is waking up. Let's see what we can discover.'
'Walk slowly and use your senses. What do you SEE? What do you HEAR? What do you SMELL? What does the air FEEL like?'
'Collect things that are already on the ground — fallen leaves, petals, interesting stones, seed pods. We respect living things by not picking them.'
Back home: 'Arrange your collection on the tray. Can you sort them into groups? By color? By type? By texture?'

slides.prompt: Create a nature display. Sort your finds into groups. Draw your favorite item in your journal and label it. Write one thing you noticed about spring.

slides.text: 'You were a wonderful nature observer today! Scientists call this fieldwork — going out to study nature where it lives.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify at least 3 signs of spring and sort collected items into logical categories?

parent_notes: Nature walks are central to Montessori education. Maria Montessori believed children need regular, unrushed time in nature to develop their powers of observation. The key is to walk SLOWLY — follow the child's pace and interest. If they want to spend five minutes watching an ant, that IS the lesson. The rule about not picking living things teaches environmental stewardship. Sorting the collection afterward develops classification skills. Over time, you can build a nature table or shelf in your home where seasonal finds are displayed and rotated. This becomes a treasured space for the child.

title: Creative Writing Introduction — Drawing and Labeling
description: The child creates a picture and writes labels or a simple sentence about it. This is the beginning of creative writing — expressing one's own ideas through words and pictures.
instructions:
1. 'Today you are going to be an AUTHOR! Authors write about things they know and care about.'
2. 'First, think about something you want to share. Maybe your seeds, a pet, your favorite food, or something from our nature walk.'
3. 'Draw a picture of it. Take your time — add details!'
4. 'Now let's add words. What is this?' Child names objects in the picture.
5. Help the child write labels using their phonics knowledge. Sound out each word together.
6. 'Can you write a sentence about your picture?' Even 'I like my cat' counts!
7. Read the sentence together. Celebrate: 'You wrote something that someone else can read!'
materials_needed: Paper (unlined for drawing, lined for writing, or combination)

slides.setup_instructions: Provide paper that has space for drawing AND writing. Unlined on top, lined on the bottom works well.

slides.text: 'You know how to read words. You know how to build words with letters. Today you're going to WRITE your own words and create your own page — like an author!'
'First, think of something you want to share with someone. What do you love? What did you see today? What did you learn this week?'
'Draw a picture of it. Add lots of details — colors, shapes, and the things that matter to you.'
'Now let's add words! Point to something in your picture. What is it?' Child says the word. 'Sound it out: what sounds do you hear? Write the letters for those sounds.'

slides.prompt: Label at least 3 things in your picture. Then try writing one sentence about your picture. Sound out each word and write what you hear.

slides.text: 'You are a WRITER! You drew a picture AND wrote words. Someone else could read your writing and understand your ideas.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child draw a picture, label at least 2 items using phonetic spelling, and attempt a sentence?

parent_notes: This is a milestone moment: the child transitions from reading OTHER people's words to writing their OWN. In Montessori, creative writing often begins with drawing, because children think in images first. The key principle: accept phonetic spelling. If the child writes 'I lik mi kat,' celebrate it! They are applying phonics to express their own ideas. Do NOT correct spelling at this stage — it discourages writing. Over time, conventional spelling will develop through reading exposure. The moveable alphabet can help children who aren't ready to write letters with a pencil but can compose words by selecting letters. Writing is thinking made visible.

title: Stamp Game Multiplication — Practice and Recording
description: The child practices multiplication with the stamp game, building fluency with the process. Emphasis on recording each problem as a written equation: multiplicand x multiplier = product.
instructions:
1. Review: 'Multiplication means taking a number many times. We use the x sign.'
2. Problem cards: prepare 6-8 multiplication problems on cards.
3. Child picks a card, reads the problem, builds it with the stamp game, counts the result, and records the equation.
4. Problems: 3 x 4, 5 x 3, 2 x 5, 4 x 4, 11 x 3, 12 x 2, 10 x 4.
5. After each problem, child writes: __ x __ = __ on their paper.
6. Check work together.
7. 'How many problems did you solve today? You're becoming a multiplication expert!'

slides.setup_instructions: Write multiplication problems on small cards. Place them face down in a pile.

slides.text: 'You've been learning multiplication with the stamp game. Today is PRACTICE day! You'll solve lots of problems and write each answer.'
'Pick a problem card. Read it aloud. Build the number that many times with stamps. Combine and count!'
'Write the equation on your paper: the number, times sign, how many times, equals sign, and the answer.'
Model one: '3 x 4. I build 3 four times: 3, 3, 3, 3. Count: 12! I write: 3 x 4 = 12.'

slides.prompt: Solve at least 5 multiplication problems from the cards. Build each one with the stamp game and record every equation. Challenge: try a problem with a 2-digit number!

slides.text: 'Look at all the multiplication you did today! Count your equations. You're building multiplication muscles!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently solve at least 4 stamp game multiplication problems and record them correctly?

parent_notes: Practice is essential for building fluency with any new math operation. The problem cards add an element of surprise and game-like quality. Mix single-digit and two-digit problems to provide appropriate challenge. Recording the equations in writing reinforces the connection between the concrete stamp game work and abstract mathematical notation. If the child makes an error, have them rebuild and recount rather than simply correcting them — self-correction is a Montessori principle. The child should feel successful and competent. Speed is not the goal; accuracy and understanding are.

title: Caring for Our Earth — Reduce, Reuse, Recycle
description: An introduction to environmental stewardship through the concepts of reducing waste, reusing materials, and recycling. The child learns practical ways to care for the Earth, connecting to Montessori's emphasis on care of the environment.
instructions:
1. 'We take care of our home. But we also need to take care of our BIGGEST home — the Earth!'
2. 'There are three things we can do to help: Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle.'
3. REDUCE: 'Use less! Turn off lights, use less water, don't waste food.'
4. REUSE: 'Use things again! A box can become a toy. A jar can hold crayons.'
5. RECYCLE: 'Some things can be made into NEW things. Paper, plastic, glass, metal.'
6. Sort activity: give the child a pile of clean items. 'Which goes in the recycling? Which is trash? Which could we reuse?'
7. 'What's ONE thing our family can do this week to help the Earth?'
materials_needed: Clean recyclable items for sorting (paper, plastic bottle, can, glass jar, etc.)
Three bins or boxes labeled Reduce, Reuse, Recycle

items: Optional: pictures of landfills and nature
slides.setup_instructions: Collect a variety of clean items: paper, cardboard, plastic bottle, tin can, glass jar, food wrapper, old shirt, etc. Label three bins.

slides.text: 'You do such a good job caring for our home — you clean up, water plants, and keep things tidy. But we have an even BIGGER home. What is it? The EARTH!'
'REDUCE means using LESS. Turn off lights when you leave a room. Don't waste water. Take only the food you'll eat.'
'REUSE means using things AGAIN instead of throwing them away. An old box can become a fort. A jar can hold your crayons!'
'RECYCLE means turning old things into NEW things. Paper becomes new paper. Plastic bottles can become playground equipment!'

slides.prompt: Sort the items on the table: which can be recycled? Which could we reuse? Which should we try to reduce using? Place each in the right bin.

slides.text: 'Every little thing we do helps our Earth. Let's choose ONE thing to do this week as a family to reduce, reuse, or recycle more.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sort items into recycle/reuse/reduce categories and suggest one way to help the environment?

parent_notes: Montessori's concept of care of the environment extends naturally from the classroom to the planet. Maria Montessori believed that children who learn to care for their immediate environment develop a disposition to care for the larger world. This lesson makes environmental stewardship concrete and age-appropriate. The sorting activity gives children practice with a skill they'll use for life. Follow through on the family commitment — if you decide to start composting, turn off more lights, or bring reusable bags shopping, involve the child. They become passionate environmental advocates when they feel their actions matter.

title: Read-Aloud: Jack's Garden by Henry Cole
description: Reading 'Jack's Garden' by Henry Cole, a cumulative story following the chain of events from planting seeds to a blooming garden, inspired by 'The House That Jack Built.'
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What do you see in Jack's garden?'
2. Read aloud — the cumulative structure builds like 'The House That Jack Built.'
3. Let the child join in on the repeated phrases.
4. Point out the detailed illustrations of insects, birds, and plants.
5. Discuss the sequence: seeds, soil, rain, sprouts, buds, flowers.
6. Connect to gardening: 'What would you plant in your garden?'
materials_needed: Optional: seeds and small pots for planting

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. If doing a planting activity, prepare materials.

slides.text: Cover: 'Look at Jack's beautiful garden! What do you think he had to do to grow it?'
Read the cumulative text with rhythm. Encourage the child to join in as phrases repeat and build.
Discuss the garden chain: 'What came first? What did the rain do? What did the bugs do? What finally bloomed?'

slides.prompt: Draw your own garden plan! What flowers and vegetables would you plant? If you have seeds, plant one in a small pot.

slides.text: 'A garden needs so many things — seeds, soil, rain, sun, and patience. Just like Jack's!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sequence the steps from seed to blooming garden?

parent_notes: This cumulative tale reinforces sequencing skills while teaching garden science. Henry Cole's detailed illustrations include realistic insects and birds that support nature study. The structure mirrors 'The House That Jack Built,' making it great for memory and prediction. Consider starting a small planting project alongside this book.
